author: mail@robbertkrebbers.nl
message: Preliminary version including apartness and constructive order theory.
body:
Before this commit a lot of our abstract theory on fields and order could not be applied to the constructive reals in CoRN. This was due to the fact that division was parametrized by a proof of () (which does not contain constructive contents) and big parts of our abstract order theory required () to be total or decidable.

From our previous experiences with CoRN we have learned that using CSetoids (setoids with apartness) everywhere is rather inconvenient in practice. Hence we only include apartness for fields instead of the whole hierarchy. Moreover, because setoid rewriting with Type'd relations does not work, we put apartness and strict order in Prop instead of Type. By incorporating type classes, and providing alternative constructors in case equality is decidable, one should not experience too much trouble from the apartness relation.

Some important changes:
* Some new classes, most importantly: StrongSetoid, StrongSetoid_Morphism, StrongInjective, Strong{Left,Right}Cancellation. Given instances of these classes we show that we have instances of Setoid, Setoid_Morphism, Injective, {Left,Right}Cancellation, respectively. One can go the other way around, in case equality is decidable, by hand.
* A complete revision of the order hierarchy. Instead of a total order, we now use a pseudo order. These interfaces are quite preliminary, especially for ordered rings and semirings: they could possibly be strengthened and tidied up.
* Include a class DecField, in which division is a total function (/0 = 0).
* A lot of renaming: Le instead of Order, Lt instead of StrictOrder, etc.
* Some tricks to avoid eager instance search (due to bug #2528).

author: eelis@eelis.net
message: Add sketch of new abstract interface for integration.
body: This new formulation no longer starts with an integration operator whose behavior is then described when applied to certain functions (this is the Bishop formulation). The basic problem with this approach is that specifying the properties this way means that one must already have some domain in which the integration operator can be used, which gets hairy if one takes possible domain restrictions seriously. The new formulation is much simpler and more to the point, because it only specifies what the result of integrating a single function on a single range must look like (namely Riemann sums). There is no greater context or implied ability to integrate anything else; all that stuff is now easily expressible in terms of this primitive.

author: mail@robbertkrebbers.nl
message: New interfaces for the rationals. Various new theorems on the rationals and int_pow. New implementation of the dyadics.
body:
Detailed changes:
* We use the field of fractions in the rationals interface. This is convenient because Frac caries a proof that the denominator is non zero. Also we have already shown that the field of fractions contains a lot of structure. Before this interface used an ad-hoc pair to represent a fraction.
* Instead of requiring an inverse of frac x y -> x / y, the interface now require an injective morphism of Q into Frac. We prove that this morphism is in fact the inverse of the above map.
* We quantify over all integers implementations instead of using plain SRpair nat. This saves double work, because before we had to prove 1.) it gives rise to the required results on any integer implementations, and, 2.) we can construct a model of the rationals given the results on a specific integers implementation (alt_Build_Rationals). Now the first follows directly.
* These changes make it much easier to prove theorems on the rationals. I have proven that each rationals implementation is isomorphic and that injective morphisms between rationals implementations are unique. Also, we directly have that every two rational implementations are order isomorphic.
* Using these uniqueness results I created a new implementation of the dyadics. Equality is defined as (m,e) = (n,d) <-> m * 2^e = n * 2^d. As a result this new implementation is shorter, compiles faster and most proofs and definitions are more easy to understand.

author: mail@robbertkrebbers.nl
message: Almost all theory regarding order revised. We now have abstract interfaces that uniquely specify the order on the naturals, integers and rationals. We also specify default implementations of these abstract interfaces.
body:
More specifically:
* New notion of a semiring order introduced.
* A lot of theory about (semi)ring orders formalized.
* Proven that a total (semi)ring order uniquely specifies the ordinary order on the naturals and integers.
* Moved Theory about nat_distance, int_abs, order on the naturals to a separate file.
* Introduced the Grothendieck ring (a ring constructed from semiring pairs). This was first implicitly contained in natpair_integers.
* The positive cone of a semiring is again a semiring. This was first this was implicitly contained in positive_integers_naturals.
* Nice notations for the nonnegative, positive and negative cone.
* Concrete orders for nearly all implementations implemented and a moreover a default order for the naturals, integers and rationals.

Also:
* Params for nearly all operations are set to hopefully gain some speedups.
* More consistent naming and various ugly proves cleaned up

This has the following advantages:
* If we define an alternative order on the naturals, integers or rationals (for example from the standard library) it follows automatically that it coincides with any other order.
* Our theorems about order also apply to orders from the standard library.
* So... hopefully a much smoother integration with CoRN in which solely the orders from the standard library are used.
* We can refer to order properties of the naturals, integers, rationals, with a common name. Also, beforehand we rarely proved any results about the order on the rationals, now we get all properties of ordered (semi)rings for free.
* If we define a ring order (todo) on the dyadics we get all these results for free as well.

Todo:
* Fix the dyadics (which are now broken) and define an order on it.
* Prove that a total ring order uniquely specifies the order on the rationals.
* Prove that the default order on the rationals is total

author: mail@robbertkrebbers.nl
message: Many changes, most importantly, maps between the dyadics and rationals.
body:
* Implicit parameters of stdlib_{ring,field,semiring}_theory fixed.
* Ad hoc hack to make fast_integers use BigN's shiftl and shiftr.
* Moved theory about rationals from interfaces.rationals to theory.rationals.
* A structure isomorphic to some rationals is also a rationals.
* The above made it possible to cleanup implementations.QType_rationals nicely.
* An embedding of fast_integers into fast_rationals. This allows for an
  embedding of the dyadics build from the fast_integers into the fast_rationals
  with which we can actually compute.
* A map to go back from the fast_rationals to the fast_integers. As a result, I
  have written an approximate embedding of the rationals in the dyadics.
* Moved theory.MinMax to orders.minmax and basically reorganized the file. Also
  dyadics now uses orders.minmax instead of his own min function.
* I am now using a dollar sign instead of a dash to denote dyadics so as to
  avoid conflicts with the notation for rationals.
* Attempted to generalize the specification of nat_pow to int_pow. Although
  theory about this is not present yet.
* Some new results about arbitrary rings and fields.
* Many dirty names cleaned up.
* New tests involving computation with dyadics.

author: mail@robbertkrebbers.nl
message: Many changes, most importantly, a better implementation of the dyadics (part 2)
body:
* Dyadics are now of the shape Z # Z. This allows for a more convenient
  formalization of the approximate field operations. Moreover, our formalization
  now follows Andrej Bauer's Haskell implementation more closely.
* Normalization and approximate multiplicative inversion on the dyadics implemented.
  Unfortunately, we are not yet able to compute efficiently with it due to the
  lack of an implementation of shift right. Currently we use an implementation,
  that is also not proven to be correct, based on euclidean division.
* The definitions of the binary operations ring_minus and field_div are now in
  interfaces.canonical_names. This way we can use them in theory.rings without
  causing dependency cycles.
* Theory about ring_minus moved to theory.rings.
* Theory about field_div moved to theory.fields.
* Theory about nat_pow moved to theory.nat_pow.
* Theory about bit shift operations moved to theory.bitshift.
* The ring and field tactics are able to solve equations involving ring_minus.
* The modules theory.naturals and theory.integers are cleaned up: more
  consistent naming of lemmas, shorter proofs, consistent use of implicit
  arguments and consistent order of presentation.
* The cut_minus operation specified in interfaces.additional_operations.
* Some theory about cut_minus in theory.cut_minus. This also includes a default
  implementation for rings, using decide (x  y) and ring_minus.
* New type classes for left and right cancellation in abstract_algebra. All
  lemmas, and uses of lemmas, involving cancellation use these classes.
* Priority of various instances in ZType_integers changed to avoid unification
  problems due to proof relevance. Also, many instances in sections are not
  global anymore due to the same reasons.
* Many dirty names cleaned up.
* Some theory about arbitrary orders in orders.orders. This mainly involves
  the relation between <, ,  and =.
* Removed some workarounds due to Coq bugs that seem to be fixed.
* New type class for ZeroNeTwo in the same style as ZeroNeOne.
* Various lemmas related to order of both integers and naturals are now
  generalized and moved to orders.semiring.
* A nat_pow implementation for signed_binary_positive_integers.
* Some tests involving computation with dyadics.

author: mail@robbertkrebbers.nl
message: Many changes, most importantly, a better implementation of the dyadics.
body:
* Dyadics are now of the shape Z # Z. This allows for a more convenient
  formalization of the approximate field operations. Moreover, our formalization
  now follows Andrej Bauer's Haskell implementation more closely.
* Normalization and approximate multiplicative inversion on the dyadics implemented.
  Unfortunately, we are not yet able to compute efficiently with it due to the
  lack of an implementation of shift right. Currently we use an implementation,
  that is also not proven to be correct, based on euclidean division.
* The definitions of the binary operations ring_minus and field_div are now in
  interfaces.canonical_names. This way we can use them in theory.rings without
  causing dependency cycles.
* Theory about ring_minus moved to theory.rings.
* Theory about field_div moved to theory.fields.
* Theory about nat_pow moved to theory.nat_pow.
* Theory about bit shift operations moved to theory.bitshift.
* The ring and field tactics are able to solve equations involving ring_minus.
* The modules theory.naturals and theory.integers are cleaned up: more
  consistent naming of lemmas, shorter proofs, consistent use of implicit
  arguments and consistent order of presentation.
* The cut_minus operation specified in interfaces.additional_operations.
* Some theory about cut_minus in theory.cut_minus. This also includes a default
  implementation for rings, using decide (x  y) and ring_minus.
* New type classes for left and right cancellation in abstract_algebra. All
  lemmas, and uses of lemmas, involving cancellation use these classes.
* Priority of various instances in ZType_integers changed to avoid unification
  problems due to proof relevance. Also, many instances in sections are not
  global anymore due to the same reasons.
* Many dirty names cleaned up.
* Some theory about arbitrary orders in orders.orders. This mainly involves
  the relation between <, ,  and =.
* Removed some workarounds due to Coq bugs that seem to be fixed.
* New type class for ZeroNeTwo in the same style as ZeroNeOne.
* Various lemmas related to order of both integers and naturals are now
  generalized and moved to orders.semiring.
* A nat_pow implementation for signed_binary_positive_integers.
* Some tests involving computation with dyadics.

author: mail@robbertkrebbers.nl
message: Notion of order on the naturals and integers revised.
body:
Now, both the integers and naturals use sr_precedes. So, in order to state
specifications of operations that can be implemented for both the integers
and naturals, the order sr_precedes can be used.

Also, sg_precedes, sr_precedes and field_precedes are now instances instead of
definitions. The priorities (respectively 10, 9 and 8) should ensure that the
right order should is selected. As a consequence we can use the notation 
everywhere.

Some theory with respect to the order on naturals (that does not hold for
arbitrary semirings) has been moved to orders/naturals.v. While it would be
convenient to move theory related to the order on integers to a separate file
too, that seems harder, because many non-order related theorems in
theory/integers.v, depend on theories about order.

author: r.oconnor@cs.ru.nl
message: Adding lemmas about ArcTangent (plus a few others).
body:
I'm adding a series of lemmas about Arctangent in a file named
tranc/MoreArcTan.v.  In additon to small colletion of lemmas on
Arctangent, I've added a few other lemmas about trigonometirc functions.
Mostly lemmas on how to prove something is in the domain of Tangent, but
also how to show that Sin x[#]Zero and Cos x[#]Zero.

I also added a lemma showing the geometric series converges on (-1,1).
This is then used to show that arctangent's power series converges to
arctangent on (-1,1).

author: r.oconnor@cs.ru.nl
body:
Lemma leEq_less_or_equal : forall x y:R, x[<=]y -> Not (Not (x[<]y or x[=]y)).

is useful when you have x[<=]y in your context and you are trying to prove a
stable (aka negative) goal.  In this case, convert your goal to the form

(Not expr)

and introduce expr, apply the above lemma and introduce (x[<]y or x[=]y).
then discharge expr into the goal and convert your goal back to it's orginal
form.

Volia, x[<=]y has turned into x[<]y or x[=]y.

author: r.oconnor@cs.ru.nl
message: Adding lemmas about limits of sequences and series of compositions.
body:
I'm adding several lemmas to ftc/Composition that about the limits of
sequences of compositions of functions, and limits of series by composing
(on the right) by a single function.

While I was at it I improved the signature for fun_Cauchy_prop_const,
changing it from old:

forall H (contH:nat -> Continuous_I Hab H),
 Cauchy_fun_seq a b Hab (fun n => H) contH.

to new:

forall H (contH:Continuous_I Hab H),
 Cauchy_fun_seq a b Hab (fun n => H) (fun n => contH).

(and similarly for fun_Cauchy_prop_const_IR).

Also, I couldn't find a lemma stating that Feq G[o]F G'[o]F' when Feq G G'
and Feq F F', so I added it to ftc/PartFunEquality.

Lemma Feq_comp : forall (J : IR -> CProp),
(forall x Hx, I x -> J (F x Hx)) -> (forall x Hx, I x -> J (F' x Hx)) ->
Feq I F F' -> Feq J G G' -> Feq I (G[o]F) (G'[o]F').

message: Declare .d files as order-only prerequisite of .vo files
body:
That way, the Makefile will refuse to try to build foo.vo if it
couldn't build foo.d, but will not give spurious warnings of the .d
files are absent, nor refuse to build a .vo file if an unrelated .d
file fails to build.

author: r.oconnor@cs.ru.nl
message: Adding leEq, greater, and grEq to the signature of ordered fields
body:
The definition of leEq varies from structure to structure.  In order for the
theorems that use [<=] to apply to the usual definition of leEq for the
structure, it is necessary to make leEq part of the signature of the ordered
fields structure.

The new signature for is_COrdField is:

Record is_COrdField (F : CField)
  (less : CCSetoid_relation F) (leEq : Relation F)
  (greater : CCSetoid_relation F) (grEq : Relation F) : CProp :=
  {ax_less_strorder  : strictorder less;
   ax_plus_resp_less : forall x y, less x y -> forall z, less (x[+]z) (y[+]z);
   ax_mult_resp_pos  : forall x y, less Zero x -> less Zero y -> less Zero (x[*]y);
   ax_less_conf_ap   : forall x y, Iff (x [#] y) (less x y or less y x);
   def_leEq : forall x y, (leEq x y) <-> (Not (less y x));
   def_greater : forall x y, Iff (greater x y) (less y x);
   def_grEq : forall x y, (grEq x y) <-> (leEq y x)}.

I have added leEq_def, greater_def, and grEq_def.  These are unfolded version of
the definitions in the structure.

I have also added default_greater, default_leEq, and default_grEq definition
that give the former definitions to assist migration to this new signature.

The lemmas approach_zero and approach_zero_weak have changed to the following
(previously) convertable types---the types were convertible before this patch,
but now the types are no longer convertable.

-Lemma approach_zero : forall x : R, (forall e, Zero [<] e -> x [<] e) -> Not (Zero [<] x).
+Lemma approach_zero : forall x : R, (forall e, Zero [<] e -> x [<] e) -> x [<=] Zero.

-Lemma approach_zero_weak : forall x : R, (forall e, Zero [<] e -> x [<=] e) -> Not (Zero [<] x).
+Lemma approach_zero_weak : forall x : R, (forall e, Zero [<] e -> x [<=] e) -> x [<=] Zero.

These lemmas were always used on goals with leEq.

This change breaks backwards compatibility moderately.  It affects the use of
auto, simpl, etc. and it is possible the users will have to change their proofs
in unpredictable ways. The most common change is to replace unfold leEq with
rewrite leEq_def.

- unfold leEq in H5.
+ rewrite leEq_def in H5.

However several other types of changes may be necessary for users of CoRN.  Here
are a few common diffs.

* rewriting doesn't work under foralls, so sometimes rewriting must be done
later than the unfolding was.

-unfold leEq in |- *.
 intros x y z H H0.
+rewrite leEq_def in *.

* and some times a bit more work needs to be done.

-apply (H N).
+pose (c:=H N).
+rewrite leEq_def in c.
+apply c.

* folding is done by rewrite <- leEq_def.

- change (Zero [<=] x) in |- *.
+ change (Not (x [<] Zero)).
+ rewrite <- leEq_def.

* inserting a rewrite step before intros.

+rewrite leEq_def in *.
 intro.

* inserting a rewrite step before application.

+rewrite leEq_def in H.
 elim (H H1).

* replacing auto with firstorder with leEq_def

-auto.
+firstorder with leEq_def.

* or adding a rewrite before auto

-apply nexp_resp_less; auto.
+apply nexp_resp_less; try rewrite leEq_def; auto.

* Rewriting currently doesn't work for IFF, so it is more difficult to replace
unfold greater.  Fortunately greater is rarely used in CoRN, and I personally
recommend against using it.

-unfold greater in H1.
+pose (H1':=(CAnd_proj1 _ _ (greater_def _ _ _) H1)).
+clearbody H1'.
+clear H1.
+rename H1' into H1.

To this end, I've removed some uses of greater by changing the types of
strict_dec_glues and strict_dec_glues' to the following (previously) convertable
types.

 Lemma strict_dec_glues : forall a b c F (Hab : a [<=] b) (Hbc : b [<=] c) (Hac : a [<=] c),
  included (Compact Hac) (Dom F) ->
- (forall x y, Compact Hab x -> Compact Hab y -> x[>]y -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy) ->
- (forall x y, Compact Hbc x -> Compact Hbc y -> x[>]y -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy) ->
- forall x y, Compact Hac x -> Compact Hac y -> x[>]y -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy.
+ (forall x y, Compact Hab x -> Compact Hab y -> y[<]x -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy) ->
+ (forall x y, Compact Hbc x -> Compact Hbc y -> y[<]x -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy) ->
+ forall x y, Compact Hac x -> Compact Hac y -> y[<]x -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy.

 Lemma strict_dec_glues' : forall a b c F, a [<] b -> b [<] c -> included (olor a c) (Dom F) ->
- (forall x y, olcr a b x -> olcr a b y -> x[>]y -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy) ->
- (forall x y, clor b c x -> clor b c y -> x[>]y -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy) ->
- forall x y, olor a c x -> olor a c y -> x[>]y -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy.
+ (forall x y, olcr a b x -> olcr a b y -> y[<]x -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy) ->
+ (forall x y, clor b c x -> clor b c y -> y[<]x -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy) ->
+ forall x y, olor a c x -> olor a c y -> y[<]x -> forall Hx Hy, F x Hx [<] F y Hy.

message: CoRN's rational structure becomes Coq's rational structure
body:
This change may break compatility because I have removed CoRN notations for the rational numbers.  But I prefer to see it as adding compatility with projects using Coq's standard rationals.  In principle, one could maintain CoRN notations, but I feel that it isn't worthwhile.

author: r.oconnor@cs.ru.nl
message: implemented fast multiplication for polynomial multiplication
body:
Previously p[*]Zero would return some not trival, but equivalent to 
cpoly_zero result.  The new mutiplication function checks if the second 
argument is cpoly_zero, and returns cpoly_zero in that case.  This keeps 
the length of polynomials closer to the degree of the polynomials.
